column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.

column5: ["'Sir,' quoth the Lawyer, 'not to flatter ye, -- You have as good and fair a battery -- As heart could wish, and need not shame -- The proudest man alive to claim.'"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["One of the thieves come back again! I'll stand close. -- He dares not wrong me now, so near the house, -- And call in vain 'tis, till I see him offer it."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['In the wide pile, by others heeded not, -- Hers was one sacred solitary spot, -- Whose gloomy aisles and bending shelves contain -- For moral hunger food, and cures for moral pain.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["What gars you gaunt, my merry men a'? -- What gars ye look see dreary? -- What gars ye hing your head sae sair -- In the castle of Balwearie?"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Drunk? - and speak parrot? - and squabble? - swagger? - Swear? - and discourse fustian with one's own shadow?"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Dire was his thought, who first in poison steep'd -- The weapon formed for slaughter - direr his, -- And worthier of damnation, who instill'd -- The mortal venom in the social cup, -- To fill the veins with death instead of life."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Yon lamp its line of quivering light -- Shoots from my lady's bower; -- But why should Beauty's lamp be bright -- At midnight's lonely hour?"]

column5: ['Whence, and what art thou?']

column5: ["It happened one day about noon, going to my boat, I was exceedingly surprised with the print of a man's naked foot on the shore, which was very plain to be seen on the sand."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['I hear a voice you cannot hear, -- Which says, I must not stay; -- I see a hand you cannot see, -- Which beckons me away.']

column5: ['And hurry, hurry, off they rode, -- As fast as fast might be; -- Hurra, hurra, the dead can ride, -- Dost fear to ride with me?']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Where longs to fall yon rifted spire, -- As weary of the insulting air; -- The poet's thought, the warrior's fire, -- The lower's sighs are sleeping there."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['It strikes an awe -- And terror on my aching sight; the tombs -- And monumental caves of death look cold, -- And shoot a chillnes to the trempling heart.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["On the Rialto, every night at twelve, -- I take my evening's walk of meditation: -- There we two will meet."]
column7: ['Venice Preserved. A Tragedy. In Five Acts.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Look round thee, young Astolpho: Here's the place -- Which men (for being poor) are sent to starve in -- Rude remedy, I trow, for disease. -- Within these walls, stifled by damp and stench, -- Doth Hope's fair touch expire; and at the snuff, -- Ere yet 'tis quite extinct, rude, wild, and wayward, -- The desperate revelries of wild despair, -- Kindling their hell-born cressets, light to deeds, -- That the poor captive would have died ere practised, -- Till bondage sunk ihs soul to his condition"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Hame came our gudeman at e'en -- And hame came he, -- And there he saw a man -- Where a man suldna be. -- How's this now, kimmer? -- How's this? quo he, -- How came this carle here -- Without the leave o' me?"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Will it please your worship to accept my poor service? I beseech that I may feed upon your bread, though it be the brownest, and drink of your drink, though it be of the smallest; for I will do your worship as much service for forty shillings as another man shall for hree pounds.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['So stands the Thracian herdsman with his spear -- Full in the gap, and hopes the hunted bear; -- and hears him in the rustling wood, and sees -- His course at distance by the bending trees, -- And thinks - Here comes my mortal enemy, -- And either he must fall in fight or I.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['An iron race the mountain-cliffs, maintain, -- Foes to the gentler genius of the plain. -- Who, while their rocky ramparts round they see, -- The rough abode of want and liberty, -- As lawless force from confidence will grow, -- Insult the plenty of the vales below.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Far as the eye could reach no tree was seen, -- Earth, clad in russet, scorn'd the lively green; -- No birds, except as birds of passage, flew; -- No bee was heart to hum, no dove to coo; -- No streams, as amber smooth - as amber clear, -- Were seen to glide, or heard to warble here."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Baron of Bucklivie, -- May the foul fiend drive ye, -- And a' to pieces rive ye, -- For building sic a town, -- Where there's neither horse meat, nor man's meat, nor a chair to sit down."]
column8: ['Scottish Popular Ryhymes on a bad Inn']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Bagpipes, not lyres, the Highland hills adorn, -- Maclean's loud hollo, and MacGregor's horn."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["General, -- Hear me, and mark me well, and look upon me -- Directly in my face - my woman's face -- See if one fear, one shadow of a terror, -- One paleness dare appear, but from my anger, -- To lay hold on your mercies"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["'Woe to the vanquish'd!' was stern Brenno's word -- When sunk proud Rome beneath the Gallic sword -- 'Woe to the vanquish'd!' when his massive blade -- Bore down the scale against her ransom weigh'd; -- And on the field of foughten battle still, -- Woe knows no limit save the victor's will."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["And be he safe restored ere evening set, -- Or if there's vengeance in an injured heart, -- And power to wreak it in an armed hand, -- Your land shall ache for't"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['And when he came to broken brigg, -- He bent his bow and swam; -- And when he came to grass growing, -- Set down his feet and ran.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Dangle. Egad, I think the interpreter is the harder to be understood of the two.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["A hopeless darkness settles o'er my fate: -- I've seen the last look of her heavenly eyes, -- I've heard the last sound of her blessed voice, -- I've seen her fair form from my sighs depart: -- My doom is closed."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Farewell to the land hwere the clouds love to rest, -- Like the shroud of the dead, on the mountain's cold breast; -- To the cataract's roar where the eagles reply, -- And the lake her lone bosom expands to the sky."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Come ye hither, my 'six' good sons, -- Gallant men I trowe ye be, -- How many of you, my children dear, -- Will stand by that good Earl and me? -- Five of them did answer make -- Five of them spoke hastilie, -- 'O father, till the day we die, -- We'll stand by that good Earl and thee'"]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["His master's gone, and no one now -- Dwells in the halls of Ivor; -- Men, dogs, and horses all are dead, -- He is the sole survivor."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['But now the hand of fate is on the curtain, -- And gives the scene to light.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['For why? Because the good old rule -- Sufficeth them; the simple plan, -- That they should take, who have the power, -- And they should keep who can.']

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["How have I sinn'd, that this affliction -- Should light so heavy on me? I have no more sons, -- And this no more mine own. - My grand curse -- Hang o'er his head that thus transformed thee! - Travel? -- I'll send my horse to travel next."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["I begin shrewdly to suspect the young man of a terrible taint -- Poetryl with which idle disease if he be infected, there's no -- hope of him in a state course. Actum est of him for a commonwealth's man, if he go to't in rhyme once."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["The slack sail shifts from side to side, -- The boat, untrimm'd, admits to tide, -- Borne down, adrift, at random tost, -- The oar breaks short, the rudder's lost."]

column2: Rob Roy. By the Author of ""Waverley,"" ""Guy Mannering,"" and ""The Antiquary."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['The Scots are poor, cries surly English pride. -- True is the charge; nor by themselves denied. -- Are they not, then, in strictest reason clear, -- Who wisely come to mend their fortunes here?']

column5: ["'Tis virtue makes the bliss where'er we dwell"]
["Heutreux qui ne livre son coeur du'a des sentiments doux et moderes et qui scait se garantir des passions violentes! --"]

column2: Six Weeks at Long's. By a late resident. Second edition. In three volumes. Vol. I.

column2: Things by their Right Names; A Novel, In Two Volumes. By a person without a name. Vol. I.
column5: ["Let us 'encompass virtue with associations more than mortal; associations whose steady light may survive the waving, and meterous gleams of sentimental illusion.'"]

column2: Things by their Right Names; A Novel, In Two Volumes. By a person without a name. Vol. I.
column5: ["Servant of God, well done! Well hast thou fought; -- And for the test'mony of truth hast borne -- Universal reproach, far worse to bear -- Than violence; this was all thy care, -- To stand approv'd in sight of God, though worlds -- Judg'd thee perverse."]

column2: The bachelor and the married man, or the equilibrium of the ""balance of comfort."" In three Volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['If I seek an interest of my own, detached from that of others, I seek an interest which is chimerical, and can never have existence. Can any thing conduce so probably to the well-being of a rational, social animal, as the right exercise of that reason, and of those social affections? All men pursue good, and would be happy, if they knew how. A steady, durable good, cannot be derived from an external cause, by reason all derived from externals must fluctuate, as they fluctutate. What then remains but the cause internal; the very cause which we have supposed when we place the sovereign good in mind - in rectitude of conduct?']

column2: Rosamund, countess of Clarenstein. In three volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['I see what you are; you are too proud, -- But if you were the Devil, you are fair.']
column6: ['Title page']

column2: Rosamund, countess of Clarenstein. In three volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Tu legasti il Cor mio con mille nodi -- Tu'l formasti di nuovo; e pol che fui -- Gentil fatto per te, -- rompesti i Lacci."]
column6: ['Title page']

column2: Varieties in woman. A novel, in three volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Howsoever, it is a kind of policy in these days, to prefix a phantastical title to a book which is to be sold; for as larks come down to a day-net, many vain readers will tarry and stand gazing like silly passengers at an antique picture in a Painter's shop, that will not look at a judicious piece"]

column2: The adventures of Roderick Random. In two volumes. Vol. I. The second edition.
column5: ['Et genus & virtus, nisi cum re, vilior alga est']

column5: ["And we - behind the Chieftain's shield, -- No more shall we in safety dwell, -- None lead the people to the field, -- And we the loud lament must swell, -- Och hone a righ, Och hone a righ, -- The pride of Albin's line is o'er."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['The live-long summer day -- She at the house end sits; and oft her wheel -- Is stopped, while on the road far-stretched she bends, -- And eye-o\'erflowing melancholy look; -- Or strives to mould the distant traveller -- Into the form of him who\'s far away. -- Hopeless and broken-hearted, still she loves -- To sing, ""When wild war\'s deadly blast was blawn.""']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["The wild glen hides an orphan boy, -- He binds his vale-flowers with the reed; -- He wears love's sunny eye of joy, -- And birth he little seems to heed."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Sweet is the falling of the single voice, -- And sweet the joining of the choral swell -- Without a pause, ta'en up by old and young -- Alternately, in wldly-measured strain."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['The appointed day arrives, a blithsome day -- Of festive jollity -- Soon as the bands are knit, a jocund sound -- Strikes briskly up, and nimble feet beat fast -- Upon the earthen floor. Through many a reel, -- With various steps uncouth, some new, some old, -- Some all the dancer\'s own, with Highland flings -- Not void of grace, the lads and lasses strive -- To dance each other down.""']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["The village all declared how much he knew; -- 'Twas certain he could write and cipher too; -- Lands he could measure, terms and tides presage, -- And e'en the story ran that he could gauge. -- In arguing, too, the parson owned his skill, -- For even though vanquished, he could argue still; -- While words of learned length and thundering sound -- Amzed the gazing rustics ranged around; -- And still they gazed, and still the wonder grew, -- That one small head could carry all he knew."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Yes! let the rich deride, the proud disdain -- The simple pleasures of the lowly train, -- To me more dear, congenial to my heart, -- One native charm, than all the gloss of art. -- These were thy charms, sweet village, sports like these -- In sweet succession taught even toil to please; -- These round thy bowers their cheerful influence shed, -- These were thy charms, - but all these charms are fled.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Alas, what sorrows gloomed that parting day, -- Which called them from their native walks away, -- When the poor exiles, ev'ry pleasure past, -- Hung round the bowers, and fondly looked their last; -- And took a long farewell, and wished in vain -- For seats like these beyond the western main; -- And, shudd'ring still to cross the distant deep, -- Returned and wept, and still returned to weep."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['How various his employments whom the world -- Calls idle, and who justly in return -- Esteems that busy world an idler too! -- He that attends to his interior self; -- That has a heart, and keeps it; has a mind -- That hungers, and supplies it; and who seeks -- A social, not a dissipated life, - His business.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["O life! how pleasant is thy morning! -- Young Fancy's rays the hills adorning, -- Cold-pausing caution's lessons scorning, -- We frisk away, -- Like school-boys at the expected warning -- To joy and play."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, -- When wealth accumulates and men decay; -- Princes and lords may flourish and may fade, -- A breath can make them, as a breath has made; -- But a bold peasantry, their country's pride, -- When once destroyed, can never be supplied. -- Ye friends to truth, ye statesmen who survey -- The rich man's joys increase, the poor's decay, -- 'Tis yours to judge how wide the limits stand -- Between a splended and a happy land."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["O'er the still lake the bell of evening toll'd -- And on the moor the shepherd penned his fold, -- And on the green hill's side the meteor played, -- When hark! a voice sung sweetly through the shade. -- She left the shade, nor marked the stranger there; -- Her pastoral beauty, and her artless air, -- Had breathed a soft enchantment o'er his soul, -- In every nerve he felt her blest controul."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['He took me up, a tender little flower, -- Just sprouted on a bank, which the next frost -- Had nipped; and, with a careful loving hand -- Transplanted me into his own fair garden, -- Where the sun always shines.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["A citizen of sober fame, -- A plain good man, and Balaam was his name; -- Religious, punctual, frugal, and so forth, -- His word would pass for more than he was worth. -- One solid dish his week-day meals affords, -- An added pudding solemnized the Lord's; -- Constant at church and 'change, his gains were sure; -- His givings rare, save farthings to the poor."]
column7: ['Epistle III. Of the Use of Riches. Moral Essays']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["I've seen sae mony changefu' years, -- On earth I am a stranger grown, -- I wander in the ways of men -- Alike unknowing and unknown. -- Unheard, unpitied, unrelieved, -- I bear about my lade of care, -- For silent, low, in beds of dust, -- Lie a' that would my sorrows share."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Fair to no purpose, artful to no end.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["A little while -- Was I a wife: A mother not so long. -- And yet methinks, when wisdom shall assuage, -- The griefs and pasions of our greener age; -- Though dull the close of life, and far away -- Each flower that hailed the dawning of the day; -- Yet o'er her lovely hopes, that once were dear, -- The time-taught spirit, pensive, not severe, -- With milder griefrs her aged eye shall fill -- And weep their falsehood, though she love them still."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Ah me! for aught that I could ever read, -- Could ever hear by tale or history, -- The course of true love never did run smooth.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Full sixty years the world had been her trade, -- The wisest wretch much time had ever made.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['After all, I verily believe that your Lordship and I are of the same religion, if we were thoroughly understood by one another; and that all honest and reasonable Christian would be so, if they did but talk enough together every day, and had nothing to do together, but to serve God, and live in peace with their neighbours.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["I know thou can'st never be mine, -- I know even hope is denied; -- Yet it's sweeter for thee despairing -- Than aught in the world beside."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['When sorrows come, they come not single spies, -- But in battalions.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Enough! it boots not on the past to dwell; -- Fair scenes of other years, a long farewell! -- Rouse up, my soul! It boots not to repine; -- Rouse up, for worthier feelings should be thine; -- Thy path is plain and straight, that light is given; -- Onward in faith, and leave the rest to Heaven.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['I saw Gaul in his armour, and my soul was mingled with his, for the fire of battle was in his eyes.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Yes, ah! Why should they know their fate, -- Since sorrow never comes too late, -- and happiness so swiftly flies? -- Thought would destroy their paradise -- No more; where ignorance is bliss, -- 'Tis folly to be wise."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['It will be proved to thy face that thou hast men about thee that usually talk of a noun and a verb, and such abominable words as no Christian ear can endure to hear....']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Wise without learning, kind and good, -- And come of Scotland's gentler blood."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Yet, always wishing for retreat, -- Oh, could I see my country seat!....']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['I pine for her. -- In crowded halls my spirit is with her. -- Through the long sleepless night I think on her; ..... I pine away for her, yet pity her -- That she should spurn a love so true as mine.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['A stream of many tides against the foes of thy people.... So Trenmor lived, and Trathal was; and such has Fingal been.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Stone walls do not a prison make, -- Nor iron bars a cage; -- .... -- Enjoy such liberty.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my trial.... only in the world I fill up a place, which may be btter supplied when I have made it empty.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['If heaven one draught of heavenly pleasure spare, ... Beneath the milk-white thorn that scents the evening gale.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Friendship, peculiar boon of heaven, -- The noble mind's delight and pride, -- To men and angels only given, -- To all the lower world denied."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["I and my sword shall earn outselves a chronicle. There's hope in't yet."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['But I will delve one yard below their mines.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Behold a man of war assailed me, -- He told me of his battles o'er and o'er; .... Of this and that commission - in the clouds."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["A sudden thrill, a startling thought, .... HIs mother's milk was stirring."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["God and our cause to friend, the venture we'll abide."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['A various host - from kindred realms they came, -- Brethren in arms, but rivals in renown.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Merciful God! how horrible is night -- Upon the plain of Atzlan! There the shout -- .... -- In one wild uproar and continuous din, -- shake the still air.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["No life to ours! -- Up to the mountains! he that strikes...... Poor house, thou keep'st thyself"]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Be thou her comforter, -- Who art the widow's friend! Man does not know -- ... --- His image who was gone. - Oh, God! be thou, -- Who art the widow's friend, her comforter."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Home, word delightful to the heart of man.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Lasting was our abode together, -- During two generations that departed like leaves. -- ... - Streams shifting their channels; -- Nettles in the abode of kings.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Here still beneath eve's soft-consenting star, -- Fandango twirls his jocund castanet."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['My son! my son! the voice of nature cried, -- Would that for thee thy father could have died.']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["O what a precious comfort 'tis to have so many like brothers commanding one another's fortunes!"]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ["Ah, little did thy mother think -- The day she cradled thee, -- To what lands thou should'st travel, -- Or what death thou should'st die."]

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Breathes there the man with soul so dead, -- Who never to himself hath said, -- .. -- As home his footsteps he hath turned, -- From waandering on a foreign land?']

column2: Clan-Albin: A National Tale. In Four Volumes. The Second Edition. Vol. I
column5: ['Elegant sufficiency, content, -- Retirement, rural quiet, frienship, books, -- Ease and alternate labour, useful life, -- Progressive virtue and approving Heaven. -- These are the matchless joys of virtuous love; -- And thus their moments fly.']

column2: The history of the renowned Don Quixote de la Mancha. Interspersed with ludicrous dialogues, rhapsodies, madrigals, and serenades. The whole replete with infinite humour and drollery. Translated from the original Spanish of Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra. column5: ["Ye sylphs and sylphids, to your chief give ear,---Fays, fairies, genii, elves, and demons, hear!---Ye know the spheres, and various tasks assign'd---By laws eternal to th' aerial kind:---Some in the fields of the purest aether play,---And bask, and whiten, in the blaze of the day;---Some guide the course of wand'ring orbs on high,---Or roll the planets thro' the boundless sky:---Our humbler province is to tend the fair,---Not a less pleasing, nor less glorious care."]

column5: ["Beware the dangerous beauty of the wanton;---Shun their enticements; ruin, like a vulture,---Waits on their conquests: falsehood too's their business;---They put false beauty off to all the world;---Use false endearments to the fools that love them:---And when they marry, to their silly husbands---They bring false virtue, broken fame and fortune."]

column2: The distressed orphan, or love in a mad house; containing an account of her being left to the care of an uncle who would have married her contrary to her inclination, to his own son, and on her refusal to comply, and having fixed her heart on a colonel, she was sent to a mad-house, where she continued till her faithful lover sham'd himself mad, and by that means obtained her liberty. Interspersed with a great many entertaining letters. [epigraph]. Written by herself, after her happy union with the colonel.
column5: ["Ambition and avarice is here display'd,---A cruel guardian, a distressed maid!---A faithful lover, who at last is blest---for having aided innocence distrest!---Justice is triumphant, over fraud and pride,---And how the cruel wretch, unpitied, died."]

column2: The memoirs of Miss Arabella Bolton. Containing a genuine account of her seduction, and the barbarous treatment she afterwards received from the honourable C--- L-----, the present suposed M-----r for the County of Middlesex. With various other misfortunes and embarrassments, into which this unhappy young woman has been cruelly involved through the vicissitudes of life, and the villainy of her seducer. The whole taken from the original letters of the said C--- L----- to Dr. Kelly, who attended her in the greatest misfortunes and distresses under which she laboured; And also from several original letters from Doctor Kelly and Miss Bolton, and from other authenticated papers in the hands of the publisher.
column5: ["Were you, ye fair, but cautious whom ye trust,---Did you but think how seldom fools are just.---So many of your sex would not in vain,---of broken vows and faithless men complain:---Of all the various wretches love has made,---How few have been by men of sense betray'd?---Convinc'd by reason, they your power confess,---Pleas'd to be happy, as you're pleas'd to bless,---And conscious of your worth can never love you less."]

column2: Adsonville: or marrying out. A narrative tale
column5: ["Oh! Love no habitant of earth thou art-- ---An unseen seraph, we believe in thee;---A faith, whose martyrs are the broken heart;---But never yet hath seen, nor e'er shall see---The naked eye, thy form, as it should be:---The mind hath made thee, as it peopled heaven,---Even with its own desiring phantasy,---And to a thought, such shape and image given,---As haunts the unquenched sould--parch'd--wearied--wrung and riven."]

column2: A journal, of a young man of Massachusetts, late a surgeon on board an American privateer, who was captured at sea by the British, in May, eighteen hundred and thirteen, and was confined first, at Melville Island, Halifax, then at Chatham, in England, and last, at Dartmoor Prison. Interspersed with observations, anecdotes and remarks, tending to illustrate the moral and political characters of three nations. To which is added, a correct engraving of Dartmoor Prison, representing the massacre of American prisoners. Written by himself.

column2: Plays prose and poetry. By Charlotte M. S. Barnes.
column5: ['""Mixed characters, such as in fact we meet with in the world, afford the most proper field for displaying, without any bad effect on morals, the vicissitudes of life; and they interest us the more deeply, as they display the emotions and passions of which we have all been conscious. When such persons fall into distress through the vices of others, the subject may be very pathetic; but it is always more instructive when a person has been himself the cause of his misfortune, and when his misfortune is occasioned by the violence of passion, or by some weakness incident to human nature. Such subjects both dispose us to the deepest sympathy, and administer useful warnings for our own conduct.""']

column2: The life and memoirs of Mr. Ephraim Tristram Bates, commonly called Corporal Bates, a broken hearted soldier: who, from a private centinel in the guards, was, from his merits, advanced, regularly, to be corporal, serjeant, and pay-master serjeant; and had he lived a few days longer, might have died a commission-officer, to the great loss of his lamentable lady, whose marriage he had intended to declare as soon as his commission was signed; and who, to make up for the loss of so dear an husband, and her pension, which then no Duke on earth could have hindered, in order to put bread in the mouths of seven small children, the youngest now at her breast, the sweet creatures being two twins, publishes these memoirs from the original papers, sealed up with the seal of dear Mr. Bates, and found, exactly as he mentioned in his last will and testament, in an  oven, never used, where, in his life time, he secreted many state papers, &c. &c. &c.
column5: ['Sublatum ex occulis quaerimus.']

column5: ["Ten' asybolum venire, unctum atque lautum e balneis, Otiosum ab animo! cum ille et cura et sumptu absumitur, Dum tibi sit, quod placeat; ille ringitur, tu rideas; Frior bibas, prior decumbas; dubia coena apponitur.----Haec, cum rationem ineas, quam sint suavia, et quam cara sint, Ea qui proebt, non tu hunc babeas plane praesentem Deum?"]
column6: ['""For you to take your place at table at free cost, annointed and just washed at the bath, with your mind at ease, whereas he is devoured with the care and expense: while every thing is being done to give you delight, he is being vexed at heart; you are laughing away, first to drink, take the higher place; a banquet full of doubts is placed before you---When you are in doubt which in especial to partake of. When you enter upon a consideration of how delicious these things are, and how costly they are, the person who provides them, must you not account him a very God, neither more nor less?""']

column2: A second tale of a tub: or, the history of Robert Powel the puppet-show-man. By Thomas Burett, Esq; The second edition.
column5: ['""Dingdong. Give me your hand--humph, you go to see fashions; you are the king\'s jester; your name is Robin Mutton. Do you see this same ram? His name too is Robin. Here, Robin, Robin, Robin; Baea, Baea, Baea. Hath he not a rare voice? Panurge. Ay marry hath he, a very fine and harmonious voice. Dingdong. Well, this bargain shall be made between you and me, friend and neighbour; we will get a pair of scales, then you, Robbin Mutton shall be put into one of them, and Tup Robin into the other. Now I\'ll hold you a peck of oysters, that in weight, value, or price, he shall outdo you, and you shall be found light in the very numerical manner as when you shall be hanged and suspended. Rabelais, Book 4. Chap. 6.""']

column5: ["I pray you, in your letters,--- When you shall those unlucky deeds relate,---Speak of me as I am. Nothing extenuate,--- Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak--- Of one that lov'd, not wisely, but too well:--- Of one, not so easily jealous: but, being wrought,--- Impatient in th'extreme: of one, whose hand,--- Like the base judean, threw a pearl away--- Richer than all his tribe: of one, whose eyes,---Albeit unused to the melting mood,--- Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees--- Their medicinal gum."]
column11: ['Use of the word ""Judean"" is possibly an archaic form of ""Indian"", which is used in texts of modern prints of Othello.', '""Judean"" indicates this epigraph is taken from the First Folio."']

column5: ['Illa quis & me, inquit, miseram, & te perditit, Orpheu?--- Iamque vale: feror ingenti circumdata nocte,--- Invalidasque tibi tendens, heu! non tua, palmas.']
column6: ["Then thus the bride: What fury seized on thee,--- Unhappy man! to lose thyself and me?---And now farewell! Involv'd in shades of night,--- For ever I am ravish'd from thy sight:--- In vain I reach my feeble hands to join--- In sweet embraces, ah! no longer thine!"]
column11: ['Translated into English by John Dryden.', 'Translation by Dryden printed directly following Virgil epigraph.']

column5: ["Then thus the fair: what fury seiz'd on thee,--- Unhappy man! to lose thyself and me!--- And now farewell! involv'd in shades of night,--- For ever I am ravish'd from thy sight:--- In vain I reach my feeble hands to join--- In sweet embraces, ah! no longer thine!"]

column2: The pilgrim, or the stranger in his own country. Containing a regular series of historical novels, digested into four books, written originally in Spanish, by the celebrated Lopez de Vega Carpio. Also Diana, a pastoral romance in four books, by George de Montemajor, with its continuation in three books, by Gaspar Gilpolo, from the Spanish original.
column5: ["If sense sublime, if thoughts the most refin'd---If what may please, with what may teach combin'd,---If female truth, if manly worth can plead,---With just delight these stories shall be read.---Nay more - when read shall nobel passion move,---And warm our youth to an heroic love.---Inspire a zeal in honour's cause to fight,---Wrongs to redress, and do the injur'd right.---Compared with glory, all things to distain,---and rous'd by Spanish wit repress the rage of Spain."]

column2: The pilgrim, or the stranger in his own country. column5: ["This noble piece in pure Castilian wrote---With honest pride, the Spanish writers quote:---Own that its worth, tho' from a foreign hand,---Makes it with justice on the summit stand.---Of all their wit - O! may this transcript find,---Usage as just, or at least as kind."]

column2: Reuben and Rachel; or, tales of old times. A novel. By Mrs. Rowson, author of Charlotte, Trials of the heart, Fille de chambre, &c. &c. Published according to act of Congress.
column5: ["When oft, by pain or grief oppress'd,---Sweety poesy, enchanting fair,---Has breath'd some heav'nly dulcet air,---And sooth'd my soul to rest.---But when her magic harp she strung,---And softly play'd and and sweetly sung;---Bidding the tranced fancy fly---O'er oceans vast from shore to shore;---Raising bright visions to the mental eye,---Of ages long since past, and days of yore;---List'ning enraptur'd to the strain,---Nor sickness, sorrow, care, or pain,---Was e'er remember'd more."]
column11: ['Located title page. Source of epigraph unknown.']

column2: Zeluco. Various views of human nature, taken from life and manners, foreign and domestic. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['--Cur tamen hos-tu---evasisse putes, quod diri consia facti---Mens habet attonitos, et surdo verbere caedit,---occultum quatiente animo totore flagellum?---Poena autem vehemens, ac multo saevior illis,---Quas et Caeditius gravis invenit aut Rhadamanthus,---Nocte dieque suum gestare in pectore tetem.']
column6: ["But why should you suppose that a man escapes punishment whose mind is ever kept in terror by the consciousness of an evil deed which lashes him with unheard blows, his own soul ever shaking over him the unseen whip of torture? It is a grievous punishment, more cruel far than any devised by the stern Caedicius or by Rhadamanthus, to carry in one's breast by night and by day one's own accusing witness."]

column5: ["The course of true love never did run smooth;---but either it was different in blood;---or else misgrafted in respect of years;---or else it stood upon the choice of friends;---or if there were a sympathy in choice,---war, death, or sickness did lay sige to it,---making it momentary as a sound,---brief as the lightening in the collied night,---that in a spleen unfolds both heav'n and earth,---and ere a man hath pow'r to say--Behold!---The jaws of darkness do devour it up;---so soon bright things come to confusion!"]
column8: ["A Midsummer Night's Dream, Act I. Scene I"]
column11: ['This epigraph is actually a series of lines spoken by Lysander to Hermia in Act I, Scene I; in the play, she responds to each of these statements, but here his lines have been compressed into one monologue']

column5: ['quae amanti parcet, eadem sibi parcet parum.--- Quasi piscis, itidem              est, amator, lenae,: nequam est nisi recens.--- Is habet succum; is suavitatem; eum              quovis pacto condias;--- Vel patinarium vel assum: verses, quo pacto lubet.--- Is dare              volt, is se aliquid posci, nam ubi de pleno promitur,--- Neque ille scit, quid det, quid              damni faciat; illi rei studet:--- Volt placere sese amicae, volt atiam ancillis: &              quoque catulo meo--- Subblanditur novus amator, se ut quum videat,              gaudeat.']

column5: ['Servorum ventres modio castigat inquio,--- Ipse quoque esuriens:              neque enim omnia sustinet unquam--- Mucida coerulei panis consumere frusta,--- Hesternum              solitus medio servae minutal--- Septembri; nec non differe in tempora coenae---              Alterius, conchem aestivi cum parte lacerti--- Signatam, vel dimidio putrique siluro,---              Filaque sectivi numerata includere porri.--- Invitatus ad haec aliquis de ponte negabit.              Sed quo divitas haec per tormenta coactas? Cum furor haud dubius, cum sit manifesta              pherenesis,--- Ut locuples moriaris, egenti vivere sato?']

column2: Love and madness. A story too true. In a series of letters between parties, whose names would perhaps be mentioned, were they less known, or less lamented.
column5: ['Governor. Who did the bloody deed?---Oroonoko. The deed was mine.---Bloody I know it is, and I expect---Your laws should tell me so. Thus, self-condemned,---I do resign myself into your hands,---The hands of justice.']

column2: Love and madness. A story too true. In a series of letters between parties, whose names would perhaps be mentioned, were they less known, or less lamented.
column5: ['---I pray you, in your letters,---when you shall these unlucky deeds relate,---Speak of me as I am. Nothing extenuate, [...]']
column11: ['Located verso facing first page of main text']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['War and love have various cares;-- --- War sheds blood, and love sheds tears,--- War has swords, and love has darts,--- war breaks heads, and love breaks hearts']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["As slow our ship her foamy track,---against the wind was cleaving,---her trembling pendant still look'd back---to that ear sile 'twas leaving;---so loth we part from all we love,---so turn our hearts where'er we rove,---to those we've left behind us!"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Now to yon mourner go,---mark the hot tears that from his eyelids flow,---and smothered sighs that all his breast dilate-- ---speak not--for comfort doth on silence wait-- ---but thou poor wido'd bird that quivering seest,---at one fel swoop thy dwelling desolate,---oh! what shall comfort thee, though o'er thy nest,---in vain may'st chirp and call for thy lost mate--"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["The sculptor's art can mould the form,---can give its shape a mein and grace,---yet cannot give that godlike charm,---the music breathing from the face.---the form Prometheus' hand had wrought---remained a lump of lifeless clay,---until the gleaming heaven he sought,---and fir'd the clod with heavenly ray."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["If thou art parentless, my daughter, hear me!---Childless I live, and never can have offspring;---but in my heart for thee a parent's love---I long have cherish'd--for  mother then,---Oh! do thou take me, and thou never shalt,---while beats this heart that loves thy gentleness,--know what it is to feel a mother's loss."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Lo! to the desert bend their venturous way,---a daring band, regardless of each toil;---beneath a youthful leader's valiant sway,---to rear their standard in a distant soil,---and open out an epire which might tame the lawless wild to cultur'd arts of peace,---bid the bleak waste the boon of plenty claim,---and cause th' accursed reign of savage times to cease!"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Mark yonder the captive! his doom is decreed,---his merciless foes to the faggot have bound him:---no pity they give; the poor white man must bleed,---while they raise the wild enorus of triumph aroung him-- ---But who speaks his freedom? What strange one is he?---Who bursts from the mountain-top down to his side?---'Tis the mocker of fortune, the fearless and free,---Whose deep-piercing ken through its mazes can see.--"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["A merry day, my boys, we'll have,---and form a happy quorum;--- confound the dog who would be grave,---while grog inspires we'll frisk it out,---just as the whim may please us;---and daddy Care will kick about,---till he no more can teaze us."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Creation's God! with thought elate,---thy hand divine I see---impressed on scenes where all is great,---where all is full of thee!---In every scene, where every hour---sheds some terrific grace,---in nature's vast o'erwhemling power,---thee, thee, my god! I trace."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["'Tis the nobility of nature, which---survives through all vicissitude of time---and fall of states; that pure and innate love---of human kind, which prompts the generous soul---to ospitable deeds, which bids it ask---the lone and friendless for its welcome guest."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Around the bowl of vanished years,---we talk of joyous seeming;===and smiles that might as well be tears,---so soft, so sad's their beaming;---till memory brings us back again,---each early tie that twin'd us,---how sweet's the cup that circles then,---to those we've left behind us!"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['I see the flowers and spreading trees,---I hear the wild birds singing;---but what a weary wight can can please,---and care his bosom ringing!---Fain, fain would I my griefs impart,---yet dare na for your anger;---but secret love will break my heart,---if I conceal it langer.']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["She felt his flame, but deep within her breast---in bashful coyness, or in maiden pride---the soft return conceal'd; save when it stole---in side-long glances from her downcast eye,---or from her swelling soul instifl'd sighs.---Touch' by the scene, no stranger to his vows,---he fram'd a melting lay to try her heart;---and if an infant passion struggl'd there,---to all that passion forth. Thrice happy swain!---A lucky chance, that oft decides the fate---of mighty monarchs, then decided thine."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['O woman! in our hours of ease,---uncertain, coy, and hard to please,---and variable as the shade---by the light quivering aspen made;---when pain and anguish wrung the brow,---a ministering angel thou!']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Speed, speed for your freedom, the war dogs are out;---their scent is a sure one, it marks out your path;---speek, speed for your safety, I hear the fierce shout---of the foes who are panting for blood intheir wrath!']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Survey his front, where wisdom sits serene,---and the bright flashing of his fearless eye;---that gallant port, that majesty of mien,---which promise deeds of unsurpass'd emprise,---such as to minstrelsy its fondest theme supplies,---and gains the palm the world may not deny."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["There is a tie, whose magic force---the power of lengthen'd years defies;---there is a thought whose staless course---a dearer tide of life supplies---than gives to other thoughts their source;---and days of gloom may intervene,---like ocean's wave its flight to stay,---and distance climes may come between-- ---they cannot--must not--check its way!---and there's a cord which love entwines---uncounsciously round kindred hearts,---which length of absence but refines,---and death alone for ever parts!"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["He came to the cot of the wild mountaneer,---and gladly its inmates receiv'd him;---he came with a tale which he told without fear,---and freely and well they believ'd him;---he came with a heart that was blithesome and gay,---and he wot not of love that could bind him---but when from that cottage he went far away,---he left his gay heart there behind him."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["There is a high and mystic spell,---with which great minds supremely sway---o'er those of grosser mould;---whose nameless potency obey-- --- the coward nd the bold,---nor of its source aright the history can tell.---on human fate in darkest hour,---its beams of light can fall,---and some its intellectual power,---before whose dazzling beam they cower,---the might of magic call."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Danger is glory's fancied world,---whose golden sands and amber seas---to dastards are unknown;---where never tributary breeze---their banner has unfurl'd---and to that wild and brilliant zone,which vulgar souls can never know,---which vulgar souls can never know---the sons of glory call their own,---tis theirs, adn theirs alone to go,---till through long years of pain and toil,---they reach its shore---they tread its soil;---then on their native land, its splendours they bestow."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["How dear is the heart-warming throb of delight,---when after long seasons of abscence and pain,---the maid he adores greets the fond lover's sight,---and close to his bosom he clasps her again."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods,---I better brook than flourishing peopled towns.---Here I can sit alsone unseen of any,---and to the nightingale's complaining notes---tune my distresses and record my woes.---Oh! thou that dost inhabi in my breast,---leave not the mansion tenantess;---lest growing ruinous, the building fall,---and leave no memory of what it was."]
column8: ['Two gentle men of verona, act 5, scene 4']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Then might you see on earth the warriors lie.---whose limbs robust could every toil defy;---inur'd the weight of ponderous arms to bear---deep in their flesh the hidden furies prey.--"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Oh, Anna! thin'st thout time or space---can ever change a love like mine;---can from my mem're 'er efface---charms there impress'd so deep as thine!---No; I may suffer and repine,---while round my head lefes tempest roll'---to death itself I may resign,---but thou shalt triumph in my soul!"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["'Tis love like this, in young and faithful hearts---the nearest bliss to heaven on earth imparts'---for holy, sweet, and full, without alloy,---nought but the fear of parting to annoy,---if time would only cease his onward flight,---nor wing away those moments of delight,---when mutual happiness eah throb attunes,---and heart with heart, and soul with soul communes,---when fearless joy wafts free o'er passion's wave,---with the first feelings sacred nature gave,---the fall's dread curse would threaten then in vain,---and paradise would bloom on earth again!"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Beneath a moving shade of fruits and flowers,---onward they march to Hymen's sacred bowers:---with lifted torch he lights the festive train---sublime, and leads them in his golden chain;---joins the fond pair, indulgent to their vows,---and hides, with mystic veil, their blushing brows."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["So peaceful rests without a stone, a name,---what once had beauty, titles, wealth, and fame.---How lov'd, how honour'd once, avails thee not,---to whome related, or by whom begot'---a heap of dust alone remains of thee,---'tis all thou art, and all the proud shall be."]
column8: ['Elegy to the memory of an unfortunate lady']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["What! shall the foes whom oft our arms have humbled---now triumph o'er us wit himpuity,---and scorn that power at which they oft have trmbled!---no, no, by heavens! we are as brave as ever,---and soon the proud destroyers of our brethren---shall feel that we have weapons to avenge them."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Yet cautious as in foeman's land,---Lord Marmion's order speeds the band,---some opener ground to gain;---and scarce a furlong had they rode,---when thinner trees, receding show'd,---a little woodland plain.---Just in that advantageous glade,---the halting troops a line had made---as forth from the opposing shade---issued a gallant train."]
column8: ['Marmion and the Lord of the Isles']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["At length the fresh'ning western blast,---aside the shroud of battle cast;---and first the ridgeo fmingled spears,---above teh bright'ning cloud appears;---and in the smoke the pennon's flew,---as in the storm the white sea mew,---then mark'd they, dashing broad and far,---the broken billows of the war-- ---wide rose the battle on the plain,---crests rose, and stoop'd, and rose again."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Oh! thou pale orb that silent shines,---while care-untroubled mortals sleep?---Thou seest a wretch that inly pines,---and wanders here to wail and weep!---With wo I nightly vigils keep,---beneath thy wan unwarming beam;---and mourn in lamentation deep,---how life and love are but a dream.']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Sooner shall the eagle of ehaven be torn from the stream of his roaring wind, when he sees the dun prey before him, the young sons of the bounding roe; than thou, O'Cathmore, be turned from the strife of renown."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["To tell red Flodden's dismal tale,---and raise the universal wail;---tradition, legend, tune and song,---shall many an age that wail prolong;---still from the sire, the son shall hear,---of the stern strife and carnage drear---of FLodden's fatal field;---when shiver'd was fair Scotland's spear,---and broken was her shield."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["ANd when my nightly couch I try,---sore harass'd out with pain and grief---my toil-beat nerves, and tear-worn eye,---keep watching with the nightly thief:---or, if I slumber, fancy chief, reigns haggard-wild in sore affright:---e'en day, all bitter, brings relief from such a horror-breathing night."]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Curse on his perjured art, dissembling smooth!---are honour, virtue, concience all exiled!---Is there no pity, no relenting ruth,---points to the parents fondling o'er their child,---then paints the ruin'd maid, and their distraction wild?"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['And now he pours his choice of fear,---in secret on Matilda\'s ear;---""Consent,a nd all this dread array,---like morning dream shall pass away;---I give the word--thou know\'st the rest.""']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Ask me not what the maiden feels,---left in that dreadful hour alone;---perchance her reason stoops or reels-- ---perchance a courage not her own---braces her mind to desperate tone.']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Sweet but of the Wilderness! emblem of all---that remains in this desolate heart,---the fabric of bliss to its centre may fall,---but patience shall never depart!---Though the wilds of enchantment, al vernal and bright,---in the days of delusion, by fancy combin'd,---with the vanishing phantoms of love and delight,---abandon my soul like a dream of th enight,---and leave but a desert behind--"]
column8: ['Lines written on visiting a scene in Argyleshire']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Farewell, thou fair day; thou green earth, and ye skies,---now gay with the bright setting sun;---farewell loves and friendships, ye dear tender ties,---our race of existence is run!---Thou grim king of terrors! thou life's gloomy foe,---go frighten the coward and slave;---go teach them to tremble, fell tyrant but know,---no terrors hast thou for the brave!"]

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Thou power supreme, whose mighty scheme,---these woes of mine fulfil,---here, firm I rest, they must be best,---because they are thy will.---Then all I want (Oh, do thou grant!)---this one request of mine,---since to enjoy thou dost deny,---assist me to resign.']

column2: The wilderness; or Braddock's times. A tale of the west. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["Be hush'd, my dark spirit! for wisdom condemns,---when the faint and the feeble deplore;---be strong as the rock of the ocean that stems---a thousand wild waves on the shore!---through the perils of chance, and the scowl of disdain,---may thy front be unalter'd, thy courage elate!---yea, even the name I have worshipped in vain---shall awake not the sigh of rememrance again;---to bear is to conquer our fate."]
column8: ['Lines written on visiting a scene in Argyleshire']

column2: The castles of Athlin and Dunbayne. A Highland story.
column5: ["---For justice bares the arm of God,---and the grasp'd vengeance only waits his nod."]

column2: Errata; or, the works of Will. Adams. A tale by the author of Logan, Seventy-six, and Randolph. In two volumes.--Vol. II.
column5: ['And there appeared a great wonder in heaven--a woman.']

column2: Gotham and the Gothamites, a medley.
column5: ["Hig.-Come, bring him out, for here we sit in justice;---Each man take a cudgel, a good cudgel:---and now attend our sentence-that you are rogues,---And mischievous base rascals--there's the point now---I take it, it is confessed.---Prig.-Deny it, if ye dare, knaves.---Boors.-We are rogues, sir.---Hig.-To amplify the matter, then; rogues ye are---and cudgeled ye shall be, ere we leave ye."]
column11: ["The beggar's bush is a 17th ce English play with unknown/disputed authorship."]

column2: The new history of Valentine and Orson, abstracted from the French, and the best English originals. With a new set of figures more expressive of the story, and better adapted to the entertainment of the reader, than any yet extant.
column5: ["Reader, this little book will let thee see,---The world is all but mutability:---Here thou mayst view the different state of things,---The rise and fall of emperors and kings,---And see success attending virtuous deeds,---For tho' late, a sure reward succeeds."]
column11: ['Work title page', 'Epigraph most likely original to the work.']

column2: History of Constantius and Pulchera; or, virtue rewarded.
column5: ["........................prepare to hear---a story that will turn thee into stone:---could there be hewn a monstrous gap in nature,---a flaw made through the centre by some god,---thro' which the groans of ghosts might strike the ear,---they would not wound thee as this story will-"]
column11: ['This adaptation of Oedipus was coauthored by Lee and Dryden.']

column2: The rebels, or Boston before the revolution. By the author of Hobomok.
column5: ["Here the free spirit of mankind at length---throws its last fetters off; and who shall place---a limit to the giant's unchained strength,---or curb his swiftness in the forward race"]

column2: The elixir of moonshine; being a collection of prose and poetry, by the mad poet. A great proportion of which has never before been published.
column5: ["'Tis vain for present fame to wish:---Our persons first must be forgotten,---For poets are like stinking fish,---That never shine until they're rotten."]
column11: ['Author of epigraph seems to be Clarke himself', 'Title Page']

column2: The spy; a tale of the neutral ground. By the author of              ""Precaution."" In two volumes. Vol. I. Second edition.
column5: ['""Breathes there a man with soul so dead,---Who never to himself hath              said,---This is my own, my native land.--""']

column2: The pilot; a tale of the sea. By the author of The pioneers, &c. &c. In two volumes....Vol.I.
column5: ['List! ye Landsmen, all to me.']

column2: Salmagundi; or, the whim-whams and opinions of Launcelot Langstaff, esq. and others. Third edition. Volume I.
column5: ['In hoc est hoax, cum quiz et jokesez,---Et smoken, toastem, roastem folksez,---Fee, faw, fum.---WIth baked, and broiled, and stewed, and toasted;---And fried, and boiled, and smoked, and roasted,---We treat the town.']
column11: ['Parody Latin and translation, falsely attributed to George Psalmanazar.']

column2: Koningsmarke, the long finne, a story of the new world. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["'This affair being taken into consideration, it was ajudged that Koningsmarke, commonly called the Long Finne, deserved to die; yet, in regard that many concerned in the affair being simple and ignorant people, it was thought fit to order that the Long Finne should be severely **********'"]
column7: ['Fragment of minutes of council in New-York']

column2: The valley of Shenandoah: or, memoirs of the Graysons. In two volumes.--Vol. I.
column5: ['Fame, honour, beauty, state, train, blood, and birth,---Are but the fading blossoms of the earth.']
column8: ['A Farewell to the Vanities of the World']
column11: ['Author of this line of poetry is uncertain. Some attribute it to Sir Walter Raleigh.']

column2: Hobomok, a tale of early times. By an American.
column5: ["Then all this youthful paradise around,---and all the broad and boundless mainland, lay---cooled by the interminable wood, that frowned---O'er mount and vale."]

column2: Yorktown: an historical romance. In two volumes. Volume I.
column5: ['In a moment, we may plunge our years---in fatal penitence, and in the blight---of our own sould, turn all our blood to tears---and colour things to come with hues of night.']

column2: Francis Berrian, or the Mexican Patriot. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Y si te acercas mas a nuestras dias,---O Clito, en las hisotrias--Veras, donde con sangre las memorias--No estuvieren borradas,---Que de horrores manchadas---Vidas tantas estan esclarecidas,---Que leeras mas escandalos ue vidas.']
column11: ['Unofficial translation: ""And if you come closer to our days,hidden in the histories you will see that where the memories were not erased with blood, the horror stained lives are revealed, you will read more scandals of life."']

column2: The buccaneers; a romance of our own country, in its ancient day; illustrated with divers marvellous histories, and antique and facetious episodes; gathered from the most authentic chronicles & affirmed records extant from the settlement of the Niew Nederlandts until the times of the famous Richard Kid: carefully collated from the laborious researches, and minute investigations, of that excellent antiquary and sublime philosopher, Yclept Terentius Phlogobombos. In five books.

column5: ['quae amanti parcet, eadem sibi parcet parum.--- Quasi piscis, itidem est, amator, lenae,: nequam est nisi recens.--- Is habet succum; is suavitatem; eum quovis pacto condias;--- Vel patinarium vel assum: verses, quo pacto lubet.--- Is dare volt, is se aliquid posci, nam ubi de pleno promitur,--- Neque ille scit, quid det, quid damni faciat; illi rei studet:--- Volt placere sese amicae, volt atiam ancillis: & quoque catulo meo--- Subblanditur novus amator, se ut quum videat, gaudeat.']

Sed quo divitas haec per tormenta coactas? Cum furor haud dubius, cum sit manifesta pherenesis,--- Ut locuples moriaris, egenti vivere sato?']

column2: Zeluco. Various views of human nature taken from life and manners, foreign and domestic. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['--Cur tamen hos tu---evasisse putes, quod diri consia facti---Mens habet attonitos, et surdo verbere caedit,---occultum quatiente animo tortore flagellum?---Poena autem vehemens, ac multo saevior illis,---Quas et Caeditius gravis invenit aut Rhadamanthus,---Nocte dieque suum gestare in pectore tetem.']
column6: ["But why should you suppose that a man escapes punishment whose mind is ever kept in terror by the consciousness of an evil deed which lashes him with unheard blows, his own soul ever shaking over him the unseen whip of torture? It is a grievous punishment, more cruel far than any devised by the stern Caedicius or by Rhadamanthus, to carry in one's breast by night and by day one's own accusing witness."]

column5: ["O 'tis a gallant vessel! but the wind --- Strives fiercely in her sails: each sleety blast --- Rifles her shrouds; while the froth'd brine o'ertops --- Her topmast's head.--Hark to that pealing gust! --- It roll'd along the mountainous waves, as 'twere --- Thunder 'mong the Alps; or the dread voice of doom.-- --- Brother spirit! I think you this bark will 'scape, --- Or all her freight of  goodly virtues, be --- Wreck'd by yon treach'rous rock? Woe's me, there's one --- Upon the lofty shore, straining each sense; --- With cries and clasped hands asking to save, --- Who if voice answer'd him, or instinct taught --- Which wave might bear him right, would instant plunge --- Into the yawning gulph; so to attain --- And share, like fate with this lone bark!"]

Nor in the bower. --- where woodbine flaunt, and roses shed a couch. --- Where evening draws her crimson curtains round, --- trust your soft moments with betraying man!"]

column5: ['Mihi quidem vita aulica usquequaque cordi non est.  Notae mihi ejus aerumnae.  Falso splendore multae ejus miseriae obtenduntur.  Fuci in ea multum, candoris parum est.  Nulla est aula quae vacat invidia, in qua non desideretur amicitiae fides, ubi voluntatum mutatio et subita ruina metuenda non sit.  Aula vera bona non novit nisi sero.  Umbris, fama, specie, fallaciiis, errore populari ducitur.  Ut eos fortunatos dicere non dubitem, quibus illa cito et cum parvo incommodo defungi datum sit.  Optabile est sibi posse vivere et musis; et cum paucis et non fallacibus amicis in agelli angule consenescere.  Aut nulla est in hoc terrestri exilio, aut ea demum vera vita est.']

column2: The history of Pompey the Little.  Or, the life and adventures of a lap-dog.
column5: ["King of the Garden, blooming Rose! -- Which sprang'st from Venus' heavenly Woes, -- When weeping for Adonis slain, -- Her pearly Tears bedew'd the Plain, -- Now let thy dewy Leaves bewail -- A greater Beauty's greater Ill; -- Ye Lillies! hang your drooping Head, -- Ye Myrtles! weep for Pompey dead; -- Light lie the Turf upon his Breast, -- Peace to his Shade, and gentle Rest."]
['---gressumque canes comitantur herilem.']
['---mutato nomine de te --- fabula narratur.']
column6: ['With a change of names, the fable is told about you.']

column2: The spirit of "the book;" or, memoirs of Caroline, Princess of Hasburgh, a political and amatory romance. In one volume. Edited by Thomas Ashe, Esq. First American from the third London edition.
column5: ['"The book" -- Any person having in their possession a certain book, printed by Mr. Edwards in 1807 but never published, with W. Lindsell\'s name as the seller of the same on the title page, and will bring it to W. Lidnsell, bookseller, Wimpole-street, will receive a handsome gratuity.']

column2: The fortunate country maid.  Being the entertaining memoirs of the present celebrated Marchioness of L---- V----: who, from a cottage, through a great variety of diverting adventures, became a lady of the first quality in the court of France, by her steady adherence to the principles of virtue and honour.  Wherein are display'd the various and vile artifices employ'd by men of intrigue for seducing young women.  With suitable reflections.  From the French of the Chevalier de Mouhy.  Vol. II.  The fifth edition, corrected.
column5: ["-----Blessings ever wait on virtuous deeds, --- and, tho' a late, a sure reward succeeds."]

column2: Abstract. A character from life. In two volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ["S'il y a quelque reforme a tenter dans les moeurs publiques, c'est par les moeurs domestiques qu'elle doit commencer."]
column6: ['If there is to be reform in public morals, it is necessary to begin with domestic morals.']

column2: The platonic lovers: consisting of original letters, in prose and verse, that pass'd between an English lady, and an English gentleman in France, under the borrow'd names of Clio and Strephon; who took affection to each other, by reading accidentally one another's occasional compositions. With a critical essay; containing some remarks upon the nature of epistolary and elegiac poetry; and on the most beautiful passages in these epistles. By the ingenious Mr. John Porter. The third edition, corrected.
column5: ['But oh! Encroaching mortal as thou art,---Let still thy spirit have the greatest part;---You may admire me all the ways you can;---Give me the lover, but keep back the man."']

column2: The wreath of friendship; or A return from India. A novel, in a series of letters. In three volumes. Vol. I.
column5: ['Prodesse et delectare.']
column6: ['To instruct and to delight.']

column2: Secret memoirs of the late Mr. Duncan Campbel, the famous deaf and dumb gentleman. Written by himself, who ordered they should be publish'd after his decease. To which is added, an appendix, by way of vindication of Mr. Duncan Campbel, against that groundless aspersion cast upon him, that he but pretended to be deaf and dumb.
column5: ["The lucky have whole days, which still they chuse,---Th'unlucky have but hours, and those they lose."]

column2: Love-letters from King Henry VIII. to Anne Boleyn: some in French, and some in English. To which are added, translations of those written in French. With an appendix, containing two letters from Anne Boleyn, to Cardinal Wolsey; with her last to Henry the VIIIth.
column5: ['Conjugium pactamque fidem non crimina posco.']
column6: ['I ask not sin of you, but marriage and a true contract.']

column2: Love-letters between a certain late nobleman and the famous Mr. Wilson: discovering the true history of the rise and surprising grandeur of that celebrated Beau.
column5: ['Pro venere saepe, pro Adonide semper.']

column2: A new voyage to the Island of Fools, representing the policy, government, and present state of the Stultitians. By a noble Venetian. Inscrib'd to the right honourable, the lord Ferdinando. Translated from the Italian.
column5: ['Multaque conquesti terris allabimur illis,---Quas procul hinc cernis; procul hinc tibi (cerne) videna est---Insula, visa mihi.']
column6: ['We came to that land you see, in the distance, (believe me the island I saw is best seen from a distance!)']
